note_text:
Patient: Amber Rivera || MRN: 8982897 || DOB: 05/22/1952
Date of Procedure: 2025-10-15 || Location: Mercy General Hospital, Portland, OR
Attending: Dr. Amanda Rodriguez, MD, FCCP

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Recurrent right-sided malignant pleural effusion secondary to metastatic breast carcinoma

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Ultrasound-guided right-sided tunneled indwelling pleural catheter (PleurX) insertion

INDICATION: 73-year-old female with metastatic breast cancer presenting with recurrent symptomatic right malignant pleural effusion requiring weekly thoracenteses. Decision made for tunneled pleural catheter for home drainage.

INFORMED CONSENT: Procedure risks, benefits, and alternatives discussed. Patient understands and consents.

With the patient in left lateral decubitus position, timeout performed confirming right side. The right lateral chest wall was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Ultrasound used to identify optimal insertion site in the 5th intercostal space, mid-axillary line. Pocket of fluid confirmed, pleural sliding absent confirming adhesions.

Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine infiltrated along proposed tract and subcutaneous tunnel path. A 3cm incision was made at the insertion site. Using the tunneling trocar, a 10cm subcutaneous tunnel was created anteriorly ending approximately 5cm from the axilla. The PleurX catheter was drawn through the tunnel with the polyester cuff positioned 2cm from the exit site.

The pleural space was entered using Seldinger technique under real-time ultrasound guidance. The 15.5Fr PleurX catheter was advanced over the guidewire and positioned in the posterior pleural space. Good flow confirmed with drainage of 1,200mL of bloody, viscous fluid which was sent for cytology, cell count, and chemistry.

The catheter was secured with 2-0 silk suture at the exit site. Sterile dressing applied. Chest X-ray obtained showing catheter in good position with improved aeration of right lung base, no pneumothorax.

SPECIMENS: Pleural fluid to cytology, cell count, LDH, protein, glucose

COMPLICATIONS: None

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal (<10mL)

DISPOSITION: Discharge home with PleurX drainage supplies and home health nursing arranged for drainage teaching and supervision.

FOLLOW-UP: Return to clinic in 1 week for wound check and drainage log review.

Amanda Rodriguez, MD, FCCP
Interventional Pulmonology

note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Christine Roberts
MRN: 1628081
DOB: 11/08/1961 (64 years old)
Date of Service: 2025-04-17
Location: University Medical Center, Phoenix, AZ

Attending Physician: Dr. James Park, MD
Fellow: Dr. Lisa Tran, MD (PGY-6)
RN: Sarah Mitchell, RN
RT: David Chen, RRT

INDICATION: Refractory hepatic hydrothorax in patient with decompensated cirrhosis (Child-Pugh C, MELD 24). Prior TIPS revision unsuccessful. Requiring twice-weekly thoracenteses with significant symptom burden. Not a liver transplant candidate.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Right hepatic hydrothorax

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Tunneled indwelling pleural catheter placement, right hemithorax

ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation (Midazolam 2mg IV, Fentanyl 75mcg IV) with local anesthesia (1% lidocaine with epinephrine)

Patient positioned in left lateral decubitus. Standard surgical timeout completed confirming right side, procedure, and patient identity. Pre-procedure ultrasound demonstrated large right pleural effusion with no loculations. Optimal entry point identified at 6th intercostal space, posterior axillary line.

The skin was prepped with chlorhexidine and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthesia was administered along the proposed insertion tract and subcutaneous tunnel. A 15mm skin incision was made at the insertion point.

Using the Rocket Medical tunneling system, a 12cm subcutaneous tunnel was created from the insertion site anteriorly toward the anterior axillary line. The Rocket IPC was threaded through the tunnel with the Dacron cuff positioned approximately 2cm from the exit site to promote tissue ingrowth.

The pleural space was accessed using modified Seldinger technique. Real-time ultrasound confirmed the guidewire position in the pleural space. The dilator and peel-away sheath were introduced, and the 15.5Fr Rocket catheter was advanced into the pleural space. The position was confirmed with aspiration of clear, straw-colored fluid.

1,800mL of transudative-appearing fluid was drained. Pleural fluid samples sent for cell count, chemistry, culture, and cytology. The catheter was secured with 2-0 Prolene sutures. Exit site dressed with sterile gauze and Tegaderm.

Post-procedure CXR showed catheter tip in dependent right hemithorax, significant improvement in effusion, no pneumothorax.

- Large free-flowing right pleural effusion
- Transudative appearing fluid
- No loculations or septations
- Catheter positioned in posterior dependent space

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: <5mL

DISPOSITION: Admitted for overnight observation given hepatic encephalopathy risk with large volume drainage. Home health arranged for daily drainage (max 1000mL/day).

FOLLOW-UP: Interventional pulmonology clinic in 2 weeks.

Electronically signed by:
James Park, MD
Lisa Tran, MD (Fellow)

note_text:
PROCEDURE NOTE - INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY

DATE: 2025-01-19
PATIENT: Dorothy Williams
MRN: 1620873
DOB: 02/14/1940
AGE: 84 years old
SEX: Female

ATTENDING: Dr. Michael Santos, MD
LOCATION: Cardiac Pavilion, Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, MD

1. Recurrent bilateral pleural effusions
2. New York Heart Association Class IV heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (EF 15%)
3. Not candidate for mechanical circulatory support or transplant

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Left-sided tunneled indwelling pleural catheter (PleurX) placement

INDICATION: This 85-year-old female with end-stage heart failure has required hospitalization 6 times in the past 3 months for symptomatic bilateral pleural effusions despite maximum medical therapy. After multidisciplinary discussion including heart failure, palliative care, and IP, decision was made for left-sided IPC given larger effusion on left. Patient and family understand palliative intent.

ANESTHESIA: Local anesthesia only (2% lidocaine) - patient unable to tolerate any sedation given severity of cardiac dysfunction.

Patient positioned semi-recumbent at 45 degrees (unable to lay flat due to orthopnea). Timeout completed. Ultrasound identified large left pleural effusion. Skin marked at 6th intercostal space, anterior axillary line.

Skin prepped with ChloraPrep. Local anesthesia infiltrated liberally along proposed tract. 3cm skin incision made. Tunneling device used to create 8cm subcutaneous tunnel anteriorly. PleurX 15.5Fr catheter threaded through tunnel.

Pleural space entered using Seldinger technique under ultrasound guidance. Catheter advanced without difficulty. Initial drainage of 800mL clear yellow fluid - drainage stopped per institutional protocol for heart failure patients (max 500-1000mL to avoid re-expansion issues and volume shifts).

Catheter secured with suture. Dry sterile dressing applied. Post-procedure portable CXR confirms good catheter position, no pneumothorax.

Fluid sent for: Cell count, chemistry, NT-proBNP

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal

COMPLICATIONS: None. Patient tolerated procedure well with no hemodynamic changes.

1. Overnight telemetry monitoring
2. Home health for IPC drainage teaching
3. Drainage frequency to be determined based on symptoms - anticipate every 2-3 days
4. Continue diuretics and guideline-directed medical therapy
5. Follow-up with heart failure team and IP clinic

Dr. Michael Santos, MD
Interventional Pulmonology

note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Miguel Perez
MRN: 6391046
DOB: 08/30/1981 (44 years old)
Date: 2025-06-17
Location: University of Colorado Hospital, Aurora, CO

Attending: Dr. Rachel Kim, MD
Fellow: Dr. Ahmed Hassan, MD (PGY-5)

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Recurrent post-intubation tracheal stenosis

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same - Grade III tracheal stenosis, 8mm web-like

1. Rigid bronchoscopy
2. Balloon dilation of tracheal stenosis
3. Biodegradable tracheal stent placement (BD-Stent, Merit Endotek)

INDICATION: 44-year-old male with history of prolonged intubation (28 days) for ARDS secondary to COVID-19 in 2021. Developed tracheal stenosis requiring multiple dilations. Has failed 3 prior balloon dilations with recurrence within 4-6 weeks. After discussion of options including T-tube, surgical resection, and biodegradable stent, patient elected for biodegradable stent trial given relatively young age and desire to avoid permanent stent or surgery.

ANESTHESIA: Total intravenous anesthesia (propofol/remifentanil)

Under TIVA, rigid bronchoscopy performed using 12mm Storz ventilating rigid bronchoscope. Airway anatomy:
- Subglottic region: Normal
- Tracheal stenosis: Located 2.5cm below vocal cords, approximately 8mm thick web-like stenosis narrowing the lumen to 5mm (Grade III, Myer-Cotton)
- Distal trachea and bilateral mainstem: Normal

Balloon dilation performed using 15mm x 40mm CRE balloon (Boston Scientific). Balloon inflated to 8 ATM x 60 seconds x 3 inflations with radial fracturing of the stenosis observed. Post-dilation diameter approximately 12mm.

Merit Endotek BD-Stent (18mm diameter x 30mm length, polydioxanone-based) selected based on tracheal measurements. Stent delivery system advanced through the rigid bronchoscope and deployed under direct visualization with the proximal and distal markers positioned 1cm beyond the stenosis margins. Stent expanded fully to approximately 16mm. Confirmation of good apposition to tracheal wall.

Post-procedure bronchoscopy confirmed patent airway through the stent with no evidence of stent migration. Mucosa intact with minimal bleeding from dilation site.

SPECIMENS: None

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: <5mL

DISPOSITION: PACU recovery, discharge home same day with post-procedure instructions. No activity restrictions. Soft diet x 24 hours.

FOLLOW-UP:
- Bronchoscopy in 8 weeks for stent assessment
- BD-Stent expected to degrade over 4-6 months
- CT airway in 3 months

Dr. Rachel Kim, MD
Dr. Ahmed Hassan, MD

note_text:
OPERATIVE REPORT - INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY

PATIENT: William O'Brien
MRN: 9721744  
DOB: 03/17/1954
AGE: 69
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 2025-04-30

SURGEON: Dr. David Chen, MD
ASSISTANT: Dr. Katherine Wong, MD (IP Fellow)
ANESTHESIOLOGIST: Dr. Paul Martinez, MD
FACILITY: Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Fractured right mainstem bronchus self-expanding metallic stent (SEMS)

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same; stent granulation tissue ingrowth

1. Rigid bronchoscopy with stent removal
2. Bronchoscopy with destruction of endobronchial granulation tissue using APC

INDICATION: 70-year-old male with history of esophageal cancer status post esophagectomy complicated by recurrent stricture of airway fistula 18 months ago for which a covered SEMS was placed in the right mainstem bronchus. Recent CT showed stent fracture with proximal wire protruding into the trachea. Patient symptomatic with worsening cough and hemoptysis.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia, jet ventilation

Under general anesthesia, the patient was intubated with a 12mm Bryan-Dumon ventilating rigid bronchoscope. Examination of the trachea revealed the fractured proximal portion of the right mainstem SEMS protruding approximately 1.5cm into the distal trachea. The fractured wire ends were sharp and had caused mucosal injury with surrounding granulation tissue formation.

A flexible bronchoscope was passed through the rigid scope to examine beyond the stent. The stent lumen was narrowed by approximately 40% due to granulation tissue ingrowth at the proximal end. The distal right bronchus intermedius appeared patent.

The granulation tissue was treated with APC (ERBE VIO, 30W, Effect 2) at the proximal stent margin, achieving adequate hemostasis and improving visualization.

Using a combination of rigid optical forceps and alligator forceps, the proximal edge of the stent was grasped. The stent was collapsed using the forceps in a rolling fashion and withdrawn en bloc through the rigid bronchoscope.

Inspection of the airway post-removal revealed:
- Mild residual granulation tissue at the former stent site (treated with APC)
- No perforation or significant bleeding
- Bronchus intermedius patent
- Right upper, middle, and lower lobe orifices patent

Final inspection showed no debris, no significant bleeding, patent airways bilaterally. The patient was extubated and transferred to PACU in stable condition.

SPECIMENS: None (stent sent to pathology for documentation)

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: 15mL

DISPOSITION: Same day discharge anticipated. Follow-up bronchoscopy in 6 weeks to assess granulation tissue recurrence.

Dr. David Chen, MD
Dr. Katherine Wong, MD

note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY PROCEDURE NOTE

Date: 2024-07-20
Patient: Isabella Bell
MRN: 8487377
DOB: 07/22/1972 (52 years old)

Attending Physician: Dr. Samuel Johnson, MD
Location: Community Medical Center, Denver, CO

INDICATION: Diffuse bilateral reticular opacities on CT chest, clinical concern for hypersensitivity pneumonitis vs. idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Pulmonary function shows restrictive pattern with DLCO 52% predicted.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Interstitial lung disease, undefined

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same (pending pathology)

1. Flexible bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage
2. Fluoroscopic-guided transbronchial lung biopsy, right lower lobe
3. Fluoroscopic-guided transbronchial lung biopsy, left lower lobe

ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation (Midazolam 4mg, Fentanyl 100mcg)

Following IV sedation with continuous monitoring, flexible bronchoscope (Olympus BF-1TH190) advanced through the oropharynx. Vocal cords normal, trachea patent. All segmental bronchi visualized and appeared normal with no endobronchial lesions.

AIRWAY INSPECTION: Complete inspection of airways to subsegmental level bilaterally. No mucosal abnormalities, masses, or obstruction.

BAL: Performed in the right middle lobe (RB4) using 3 x 60mL aliquots of sterile saline. Return approximately 90mL of slightly cloudy fluid. Sent for cell count with differential, cultures (bacterial, fungal, AFB), and cytology.

Using fluoroscopic guidance (C-arm positioned for AP view), the bronchoscope was advanced into the right lower lobe basal segments. The forceps (2.0mm alligator-type) were advanced under fluoroscopic visualization, positioning the forceps approximately 1-2cm from the pleural surface. 6 transbronchial biopsies were obtained from RB9 and RB10.

The bronchoscope was then repositioned to the left lower lobe. Under fluoroscopy, 5 transbronchial biopsies were obtained from the left lower lobe (LB9-10), again positioning 1-2cm from the pleura.

After biopsies, the biopsy sites were irrigated with cold saline. Bleeding was minimal and self-limited. Final bronchoscopic inspection showed no significant bleeding or airway abnormality.

FLUOROSCOPY TIME: 2.3 minutes
RADIATION DOSE: 38 mGy·cm²

- BAL: Cytology, cell count with diff, bacterial/fungal/AFB culture
- TBLB RLL (6 specimens): Surgical pathology
- TBLB LLL (5 specimens): Surgical pathology

COMPLICATIONS: None. No pneumothorax on post-procedure CXR.

EBL: <10mL

DISPOSITION: Recovery in PACU x 2 hours. Post-procedure CXR negative for pneumothorax. Discharge home with standard bronchoscopy precautions.

FOLLOW-UP: Return to clinic in 1 week for pathology results. If non-diagnostic, will discuss transbronchial cryobiopsy vs. surgical lung biopsy.

Samuel Johnson, MD
Pulmonary & Critical Care Medicine

note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY PROCEDURE NOTE

Date: 2025-01-20
Patient: Justin Nelson
MRN: 6728785
DOB: 07/22/1971 (54 years old)

Attending Physician: Dr. Samuel Johnson, MD
Location: Community Medical Center, Denver, CO

INDICATION: Diffuse bilateral reticular opacities on CT chest, clinical concern for hypersensitivity pneumonitis vs. idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Pulmonary function shows restrictive pattern with DLCO 52% predicted.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Interstitial lung disease, undefined

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same (pending pathology)

PROCEDURE: 
1. Flexible bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage
2. Fluoroscopic-guided transbronchial lung biopsy, right lower lobe
3. Fluoroscopic-guided transbronchial lung biopsy, left lower lobe

ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation (Midazolam 4mg, Fentanyl 100mcg)

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
Following IV sedation with continuous monitoring, flexible bronchoscope (Olympus BF-1TH190) passed through the oropharynx. Vocal cords normal, trachea clear. All segmental bronchi examined and appeared normal with no endobronchial lesions.

AIRWAY INSPECTION: Complete inspection of airways to subsegmental level bilaterally. No mucosal abnormalities, masses, or obstruction.

BAL: Completed in the right middle lobe (RB4) using 3 x 60mL aliquots of sterile saline. Return approximately 90mL of slightly cloudy fluid. Sent for cell count with differential, cultures (bacterial, fungal, AFB), and cytology.

TRANSBRONCHIAL BIOPSIES:
Using fluoroscopic guidance (C-arm positioned for AP view), the bronchoscope was passed into the right lower lobe basal segments. The forceps (2.0mm alligator-type) were passed under fluoroscopic visualization, positioning the forceps approximately 1-2cm from the pleural surface. 6 transbronchial biopsies were acquired from RB9 and RB10.

The bronchoscope was then repositioned to the left lower lobe. Under fluoroscopy, 5 transbronchial biopsies were acquired from the left lower lobe (LB9-10), again positioning 1-2cm from the pleura.

After biopsies, the biopsy sites were irrigated with cold saline. Bleeding was minimal and self-limited. Final bronchoscopic inspection exhibited no significant bleeding or airway abnormality.

FLUOROSCOPY TIME: 2.3 minutes
RADIATION DOSE: 38 mGy·cm²

SPECIMENS:
- BAL: Cytology, cell count with diff, bacterial/fungal/AFB culture
- TBLB RLL (6 specimens): Surgical pathology
- TBLB LLL (5 specimens): Surgical pathology

COMPLICATIONS: None. No pneumothorax on post-procedure CXR.

EBL: <10mL

DISPOSITION: Recovery in PACU x 2 hours. Post-procedure CXR negative for pneumothorax. Discharge home with standard bronchoscopy precautions.

FOLLOW-UP: Return to clinic in 1 week for pathology results. If non-diagnostic, will discuss transbronchial cryobiopsy vs. surgical lung biopsy.

Samuel Johnson, MD
Pulmonary & Critical Care Medicine

note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY REPORT

Patient: Tyler Taylor
MRN: 6349126
Date of Birth: 11/03/1985
Date of Procedure: 2025-05-19
Location: Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, OH

Attending: Dr. Erin McCarthy, MD
Fellow: Dr. Alex Rivera, MD (PGY-7)
RN: Jennifer Adams
RT: Marcus Thompson

INDICATION: 42-year-old African American male with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and scattered bilateral upper lobe perilymphatic nodules on CT chest. Clinical presentation consistent with pulmonary sarcoidosis. Bronchoscopy for tissue diagnosis.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Suspected pulmonary sarcoidosis, Stage II

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same (pending pathology)

1. Flexible bronchoscopy
2. Bronchoalveolar lavage
3. Fluoroscopic-guided transbronchial lung biopsy, right upper lobe

SEDATION: Moderate sedation (Versed 3mg, Fentanyl 75mcg) with topical lidocaine

Patient was sedated and bronchoscope introduced via oral route. Airway examination revealed normal vocal cords, patent trachea, and normal-appearing carina. All visible airways were free of endobronchial abnormalities. Mucosa appeared normal throughout.

BAL was performed in the right middle lobe using 150mL sterile saline (3 x 50mL). Approximately 75mL of slightly turbid fluid was recovered and sent for cell count, differential, CD4/CD8 ratio, cultures, and cytology.

For transbronchial biopsies, the bronchoscope was advanced into the right upper lobe. Using biplanar fluoroscopy (AP and lateral views), the biopsy forceps (standard cup forceps) were advanced into the RUL anterior segment (RB3) and positioned approximately 2cm from the pleural surface. 8 biopsies were obtained from the right upper lobe, targeting areas of perilymphatic nodularity.

Each specimen was placed in formalin and examined visually - multiple fragments appeared adequate in size. Minimal bleeding occurred, controlled with wedge technique. Repeat fluoroscopy at end of procedure showed no pneumothorax.

- Total fluoro time: 1.8 min
- DAP: 24 mGy·cm²

1. BAL - Cell count/diff, CD4/CD8 ratio, bacterial/fungal/AFB cultures, PCP DFA, cytology
2. TBLB RUL x 8 - Surgical pathology with request for special stains (GMS, AFB)

COMPLICATIONS: None

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: <5mL

POST-PROCEDURE: Patient recovered well. CXR 2 hours post-procedure showed no pneumothorax. Patient discharged home in stable condition.

IMPRESSION: Airways grossly normal. TBLB and BAL obtained for suspected sarcoidosis workup. Await pathology for non-caseating granulomas and BAL lymphocytosis/elevated CD4:CD8 ratio to confirm diagnosis.

FOLLOW-UP: Return to sarcoidosis clinic in 2 weeks for results.

Erin McCarthy, MD
Alex Rivera, MD

CT chest showed bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis and tree-in-bud opacities. Sputum cultures pending. Bronchoscopy for airway inspection and clearance of blood/secretions.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Diffuse bronchiectasis with mucopurulent secretions; no endobronchial lesion or active bleeding source identified

PROCEDURE: Diagnostic flexible bronchoscopy with therapeutic suctioning

SEDATION: Moderate sedation (Midazolam 3mg IV, Fentanyl 50mcg IV)

The patient was sedated and the flexible bronchoscope (Olympus BF-P190) was introduced via the oropharynx. The vocal cords appeared normal without lesions or edema. The trachea was patent with normal mucosa. Carina was sharp.

- Right mainstem: Patent. Old blood coating the mucosa.
- Right upper lobe: Multiple segments with thick mucopurulent secretions and old blood. Significant bronchiectatic changes. No endobronchial lesions. No active bleeding visualized.
- Bronchus intermedius: Patent with mild inflammation
- Right middle lobe: Mucopurulent secretions, no masses
- Right lower lobe: Bronchiectatic changes, thick secretions
- Left mainstem: Patent, old blood noted
- Left upper lobe: Similar bronchiectatic changes with mucopurulent secretions. No tumor or active bleeding.
- Lingula: Mild secretions
- Left lower lobe: Bronchiectasis, mucopurulent secretions, no source of bleeding identified

Extensive suctioning performed throughout all visualized airways. Large quantities of thick mucopurulent secretions and old blood were cleared from bilateral bronchi. No single bleeding source could be identified - the hemoptysis appears to be diffuse from inflamed bronchiectatic airways.

No biopsy was performed as no discrete lesion identified. No BAL performed as secretions already sent from suctioning.

- Bronchial aspirate/secretions: Bacterial culture, fungal culture, AFB culture, cytology

COMPLICATIONS: None. No active bleeding during or after procedure.

EBL: Trace

POST-PROCEDURE: Patient tolerated well. No respiratory distress. CXR unchanged from pre-procedure.

IMPRESSION & PLAN:
1. Diffuse bilateral bronchiectasis with mucopurulent secretions - no discrete bleeding source identified
2. Hemoptysis likely from diffuse bronchiectatic mucosal inflammation with superimposed infection
3. No endobronchial malignancy identified
4. Continue empiric antibiotics pending cultures
5. Pulmonary hygiene with chest physiotherapy
6. Follow-up in 2 weeks; consider repeat CT if hemoptysis persists

Dr. Jennifer Liu, MD
Pulmonary/Critical Care

note_text:
OPERATIVE REPORT - INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY / THORACIC SURGERY

DATE: 2025-08-15
PATIENT: Linda Thompson
MRN: 9503280
DOB: 09/28/1959 (65 years old)

IP: Dr. Mark Anderson, MD (started case)
Thoracic Surgery: Dr. Sarah Kim, MD (completed case after conversion)

LOCATION: Main OR, Emory University Hospital, Atlanta, GA

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Right-sided exudative pleural effusion, unknown etiology

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Dense pleural adhesions with loculated effusion; trapped lung

PLANNED PROCEDURE: Medical thoracoscopy (pleuroscopy) with pleural biopsy and potential talc poudrage

1. Attempted medical thoracoscopy (aborted)
2. Conversion to VATS (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery)
3. VATS lysis of adhesions
4. VATS pleural biopsy
5. Decortication (partial)
6. Chest tube placement

INDICATION: 65-year-old female with 2-month history of progressive dyspnea. CT chest revealed large right pleural effusion with mild enhancement of pleura concerning for malignancy. Thoracentesis x 2 showed exudative effusion with negative cytology. Medical thoracoscopy planned for definitive diagnosis and potential pleurodesis.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube (left-sided)

MEDICAL THORACOSCOPY ATTEMPT (Dr. Anderson):
Patient positioned in left lateral decubitus. After induction of general anesthesia and lung isolation, the right chest was prepped and draped. Ultrasound examination revealed a small pocket of fluid in the mid-axillary line but significant lung adherence to chest wall throughout.

A 2cm incision was made in the 6th intercostal space. Upon blunt dissection into the pleural space, immediate dense adhesions were encountered. The 7mm trocar could not be safely advanced due to extensive lung-to-chest-wall adhesions. A small pocket of loculated fluid (~200mL) was drained but no window could be created for safe pleuroscopy. Multiple attempts at different intercostal spaces (5th, 7th) encountered similar dense adhesions.

DECISION TO CONVERT: After thorough discussion with thoracic surgery colleagues and the patient's family (who had been counseled preoperatively about this possibility), the decision was made to convert to VATS for safe completion of the procedure.

VATS PROCEDURE (Dr. Kim):
The incision was extended and a 10mm port placed under direct vision where a small pleural space was identified. Two additional 5mm ports were placed. Dense adhesions were found throughout the hemithorax. Using a combination of blunt dissection, electrocautery, and harmonic scalpel, extensive adhesiolysis was performed over approximately 90 minutes.

Findings:
- Dense fibrinous adhesions throughout
- Thickened visceral pleura with trapped lung
- Nodular thickening of parietal pleura (multiple biopsies taken)
- Approximately 500mL of loculated, amber-colored fluid drained

Multiple parietal pleural biopsies were obtained from chest wall and diaphragmatic pleura. Partial decortication of the visceral pleura was performed to allow lung expansion, though complete expansion could not be achieved due to chronic entrapment.

A 28Fr chest tube was placed. Negative-pressure water seal established. Lung expansion approximately 70% at end of case.

- Pleural fluid: Cytology, cell count, chemistry, cultures, adenosine deaminase
- Pleural biopsies (multiple): Surgical pathology

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: 150mL

COMPLICATIONS: None intraoperatively. Conversion was planned contingency.

DISPOSITION: Transferred to SICU for overnight monitoring. Chest tube to suction.

POST-OPERATIVE PLAN:
1. Monitor chest tube output
2. CXR in AM
3. Await pathology - concern for malignant mesothelioma or chronic fibrinous pleuritis
4. If lung remains trapped, may require chronic indwelling pleural catheter

Dr. Mark Anderson, MD - Interventional Pulmonology
Dr. Sarah Kim, MD - Thoracic Surgery

INDICATION: 67-year-old female with 2-month history of progressive dyspnea. CT chest demonstrated large right pleural effusion with mild enhancement of pleura concerning for malignancy. Thoracentesis x 2 demonstrated exudative effusion with negative cytology. Medical thoracoscopy planned for definitive diagnosis and potential pleurodesis.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube (left-sided)

PROCEDURE NARRATIVE:

MEDICAL THORACOSCOPY ATTEMPT (Dr. Anderson):
Patient positioned in left lateral decubitus. After induction of general anesthesia and lung isolation, the right chest was prepped and draped. Ultrasound examination demonstrated a small pocket of fluid in the mid-axillary line but significant lung adherence to chest wall throughout.

A 2cm incision was made in the 6th intercostal space. Upon blunt dissection into the pleural space, immediate dense adhesions were encountered. The 7mm trocar could not be safely passed due to extensive lung-to-chest-wall adhesions. A small pocket of loculated fluid (~200mL) was drained but no window could be created for safe pleuroscopy. Multiple attempts at different intercostal spaces (5th, 7th) encountered similar dense adhesions.

DECISION TO CONVERT: After thorough discussion with thoracic surgery colleagues and the patient's family (who had been counseled preoperatively about this possibility), the decision was made to convert to VATS for safe completion of the procedure.

VATS PROCEDURE (Dr. Kim):
The incision was extended and a 10mm port positioned under direct vision where a small pleural space was found. Two additional 5mm ports were positioned. Dense adhesions were found throughout the hemithorax. Using a combination of blunt dissection, electrocautery, and harmonic scalpel, extensive adhesiolysis was accomplished over approximately 90 minutes.

Findings:
- Dense fibrinous adhesions throughout
- Thickened visceral pleura with trapped lung
- Nodular thickening of parietal pleura (multiple biopsies taken)
- Approximately 500mL of loculated, amber-colored fluid drained

Multiple parietal pleural biopsies were gathered from chest wall and diaphragmatic pleura. Partial decortication of the visceral pleura was accomplished to allow lung expansion, though complete expansion could not be achieved due to chronic entrapment.

A 28Fr chest tube was positioned. Negative-pressure water seal established. Lung expansion approximately 70% at end of case.

SPECIMENS:
- Pleural fluid: Cytology, cell count, chemistry, cultures, adenosine deaminase
- Pleural biopsies (multiple): Surgical pathology

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: 150mL

COMPLICATIONS: None intraoperatively. Conversion was planned contingency.

DISPOSITION: Transferred to SICU for overnight monitoring. Chest tube to suction.

POST-OPERATIVE PLAN:
1. Monitor chest tube output
2. CXR in AM
3. Await pathology - concern for malignant mesothelioma or chronic fibrinous pleuritis
4. If lung remains trapped, may require chronic indwelling pleural catheter

Dr. Mark Anderson, MD - Interventional Pulmonology
Dr. Sarah Kim, MD - Thoracic Surgery

note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Larry Evans
MRN: 6646405
DOB: 06/20/1960 (65 years old)
Date of Procedure: 2025-09-29
Location: Stanford Medical Center, Palo Alto, CA

Attending: Dr. Priya Patel, MD
Fellow: Dr. Kevin Nguyen, MD (PGY-6)
RN: Anna Martinez
RT: Brian Lee

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Persistent bronchopleural fistula (BPF) with prolonged air leak, post right upper lobectomy for lung cancer (POD #14)

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy with endobronchial valve placement for bronchopleural fistula/air leak closure

INDICATION: 65-year-old male status post right upper lobectomy for stage IIA squamous cell carcinoma 14 days ago, complicated by persistent air leak via chest tube (continuous, >500mL/breath). CT chest shows persistent right apical pneumothorax with bronchial stump intact but suspected peripheral alveolar-pleural fistula in the remaining RML/RLL. Given poor surgical candidacy for re-thoracotomy (COPD, recent surgery, poor nutritional status), endobronchial valve placement was planned for non-surgical management of the air leak.

NOTE: This is NOT a BLVR procedure for emphysema/lung volume reduction. The indication is therapeutic air leak closure in the setting of BPF.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia (TIVA) with single-lumen ETT

Patient intubated and positioned supine. Flexible bronchoscopy performed. Airway inspection revealed:
- Trachea: Normal
- Right bronchial stump: Healing well, no gross leak
- Right bronchus intermedius: Patent
- Right middle lobe: Patent, normal appearance
- Right lower lobe: Segmental bronchi appeared inflamed but patent
- Left lung: Normal

Balloon occlusion testing was performed to identify the leaking segment. Sequential balloon occlusion of right lower lobe segments revealed:
- RB6 (superior segment): Partial reduction in air leak
- RB7-10 (basal segments): Further reduction with RB9 occlusion
- Combined RB6 + RB9 occlusion: Complete cessation of air leak

Based on balloon occlusion testing, decision was made to place endobronchial valves in RB6 and RB9.

Valve placement:
1. RB6 (superior segment): Zephyr 4.0mm EBV deployed. Good fit, no air flow around valve.
2. RB9 (lateral basal segment): Zephyr 4.0-LP EBV deployed. Good fit.

Post-valve bronchoscopy confirmed valves in good position. Patient's chest tube placed to water seal at end of procedure.

Immediate post-procedure assessment showed COMPLETE CESSATION of air leak on the chest tube drainage system.

- Zephyr EBV 4.0mm x 1 (RB6)
- Zephyr EBV 4.0-LP x 1 (RB9)

SPECIMENS: None

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: Minimal

DISPOSITION: Return to thoracic surgery floor. Chest tube to water seal. If no air leak for 48 hours, will remove chest tube.

FOLLOW-UP: Will monitor for valve expectoration. Repeat bronchoscopy in 6-8 weeks for potential valve removal if air leak remains resolved. Valves may be permanent if necessary.

Dr. Priya Patel, MD
Dr. Kevin Nguyen, MD

note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY PROCEDURE NOTE

Date: 2025-04-04
Patient: Stephanie Allen
MRN: 1760974
DOB: 12/05/1965 (60 years old)

Attending: Dr. Robert Chen, MD
Cytopathologist: Dr. Elizabeth Taylor, MD (ROSE)
Location: UCLA Medical Center, Los Angeles, CA

INDICATION: 60-year-old female non-smoker with 2.8cm RUL spiculated nodule (PET avid, SUVmax 8.2) and enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes on CT (Station 4R 1.8cm, Station 7 2.1cm, Station 4L 1.2cm). Referred for EBUS-TBNA staging prior to planned surgical resection if N2/N3 negative.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Right upper lobe lung mass concerning for primary lung malignancy; mediastinal lymphadenopathy for staging

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same; mediastinal lymph nodes sampled - ROSE benign at all stations

PROCEDURE: Linear EBUS bronchoscopy with transbronchial needle aspiration of mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes (5 stations)

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia with LMA

The EBUS bronchoscope (Olympus BF-UC180F) was introduced through the LMA. Systematic mediastinal staging was performed.

STATION-BY-STATION SAMPLING:

Station 7 (Subcarinal):
- Size: 22mm short axis, oval, heterogeneous, no CHS
- Elastography: Score 4 (suspicious)
- Sampling: 22G FNA needle, 4 passes
- ROSE: Abundant lymphocytes, no malignant cells, ADEQUATE - BENIGN

Station 4R (Right lower paratracheal):
- Size: 18mm short axis, round, heterogeneous
- Elastography: Score 3 (indeterminate)
- Sampling: 22G FNA needle, 4 passes  
- ROSE: Lymphocytes with scattered histiocytes, no malignant cells, ADEQUATE - BENIGN

Station 4L (Left lower paratracheal):
- Size: 12mm short axis, oval, homogeneous, CHS present
- Elastography: Score 2 (benign-appearing)
- Sampling: 22G FNA needle, 3 passes
- ROSE: Reactive lymphocytes, ADEQUATE - BENIGN

Station 10R (Right hilar):
- Size: 14mm short axis
- Sampling: 22G FNA needle, 3 passes
- ROSE: Lymphocytes and bronchial cells, ADEQUATE - BENIGN

Station 11R (Right interlobar):
- Size: 11mm short axis
- Sampling: 22G FNA needle, 3 passes
- ROSE: Lymphocytes, ADEQUATE - BENIGN

All samples sent for cell block and final cytopathology.

No complications. Airways examined and appeared normal. No endobronchial lesion at RUL orifice.

ROSE SUMMARY (Dr. Taylor):
"5 stations sampled with adequate lymphocyte material at all stations. No malignant cells identified at any station. Recommend final pathology confirmation. If staging remains N0 on final path, patient may proceed with planned surgical resection. If clinical suspicion remains high despite negative EBUS, recommend surgical staging (mediastinoscopy) given substantial adenopathy and risk of sampling error."

- Station 7: Cytology, cell block
- Station 4R: Cytology, cell block
- Station 4L: Cytology, cell block
- Station 10R: Cytology, cell block
- Station 11R: Cytology, cell block

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: <5mL

1. EBUS-TBNA of 5 mediastinal/hilar stations performed for lung cancer staging
2. ROSE negative for malignancy at all stations
3. Pending final cytopathology confirmation

1. Await final pathology (3-5 days)
2. Discussed with patient: If final pathology benign at all stations, will recommend surgical mediastinoscopy given size of station 7 and 4R nodes and high suspicion for malignancy based on primary lesion PET characteristics
3. Thoracic surgery consultation placed for mediastinoscopy
4. If mediastinoscopy also negative, patient will proceed with lobectomy + lymph node dissection

Dr. Robert Chen, MD
Interventional Pulmonology

OPERATIVE REPORT - INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY
Date: 2025-07-05
Patient: Joseph Kim | MRN: 2685620 | DOB: 01/15/1964

Attending: Dr. James Walker, MD
Location: Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA

PREOP DX: Recurrent tracheomalacia with carinal involvement, s/p prior metallic stent placement with stent-in-stent failure

POSTOP DX: Same

1. Rigid bronchoscopy
2. Removal of prior SEMS
3. Silicone Y-stent (Dumon) placement

ANESTHESIA: General, jet ventilation

PROCEDURE: Under GA with rigid bronchoscopy (14mm Dumon), the previously placed covered SEMS was removed using rigid forceps with en bloc extraction. Tracheomalacia confirmed with >75% collapse on expiration involving distal trachea and proximal mainstems bilaterally.

A Novatech silicone Y-stent (18mm trachea, 14mm bilateral limbs, 50mm body length) was loaded on the deployment rod. Under direct visualization, the Y-stent was advanced and deployed with the carinal spur appropriately positioned. Both mainstem limbs expanded well. Post-deployment bronchoscopy confirmed patent airways bilaterally, good stent positioning, no mucus impaction.

COMPLICATIONS: None
EBL: 10mL
DISPOSITION: PACU, discharge same day

Dr. James Walker, MD

COMPLICATIONS: Mild bleeding - self-limited
DISPOSITION: Outpatient discharge after 2hr CXR

note_text:
THORACOSCOPY PROCEDURE NOTE
Date: 2025-11-26
Patient: Emily Ruiz | MRN: 1095765 | Age: 72M
Attending: Dr. Lisa Chang, MD
Location: Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, Los Angeles, CA

INDICATION: Recurrent right malignant pleural effusion (lung adenocarcinoma, EGFR+). Prior thoracenteses x 4. Patient prefers pleurodesis over IPC.

1. Medical thoracoscopy (pleuroscopy)
2. Pleural biopsy
3. Talc poudrage pleurodesis
4. Chest tube placement

ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation with local anesthesia

PROCEDURE: Patient in left lateral decubitus. Entry via 7th ICS mid-axillary line. 1000mL serous fluid drained. Thoracoscope (LTF-160) introduced. Findings:
- Parietal pleura: Diffuse nodular studding, largest 5mm
- Visceral pleura: Scattered nodules
- Diaphragm: Nodular implants
- Lung: Partially trapped, ~70% expansion achievable

Multiple biopsies taken from parietal and diaphragmatic pleura using flexible forceps (8 specimens total).

After fluid evacuation and lung re-expansion to ~80%, talc poudrage performed (4g sterile talc via atomizer, even distribution). 24Fr chest tube placed, connected to suction (-20cmH2O).

SPECIMENS: Pleural biopsies x 8, pleural fluid (cytology, cell block)
COMPLICATIONS: None
EBL: Minimal
DISPOSITION: Admit for chest tube management. Target removal in 48-72hr if output <150mL/day and lung expanded.

Dr. Lisa Chang, MD

coding_review.overall_assessment: Medical thoracoscopy with both biopsy and pleurodesis - both codes reportable.

CLINICAL INDICATION AND PREOPERATIVE ASSESSMENT
----------------------------------------
The patient presented with suspected sarcoidosis. Following comprehensive multidisciplinary evaluation and informed consent discussion detailing procedural risks, benefits, and alternatives, the patient elected to proceed with the proposed intervention.

PROCEDURAL METHODOLOGY AND TECHNIQUE
----------------------------------------

Linear Ebus:
Endobronchial ultrasound-guided transbronchial needle aspiration was performed utilizing real-time sonographic guidance for precise lymph node targeting. Systematic sampling was conducted at stations 7, 4R, 11L, 11R. Rapid on-site cytological evaluation was employed to ensure specimen adequacy. 

INTRAPROCEDURAL FINDINGS
----------------------------------------
ROSE positive for non-caseating granulomas at multiple stations - consistent with sarcoidosis. No necrosis identified.


POSTPROCEDURAL ASSESSMENT AND DISPOSITION
----------------------------------------
The procedure was completed without immediate complications. The patient demonstrated hemodynamic stability throughout and was transferred to the recovery area in satisfactory condition.

Date: 2024-01-26
Patient: Roger Wang | MRN: 1924784 | Age: 45M
Attending: Dr. Nancy Adams, MD
Location: Northwestern Memorial Hospital, Chicago, IL

INDICATION: Immunocompromised patient (AML s/p allo-HSCT day +45) with new bilateral infiltrates on CT, febrile, hypoxic. BAL for infectious workup.

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy with BAL

ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation (intubated in MICU, FiO2 60%)

PROCEDURE: Bronchoscope advanced via ETT. Airways examined:
- Diffuse mucosal edema and erythema throughout
- Scant mucopurulent secretions
- No endobronchial lesions

BAL performed in RML (area of maximal infiltrate on CT):
- Instilled 150mL sterile saline in 3 aliquots
- Returned 60mL slightly cloudy fluid
- Sent for: Cell count, bacterial/fungal/viral cultures, PCP DFA, CMV PCR, galactomannan, respiratory viral panel, cytology

SPECIMENS: BAL fluid - comprehensive infectious workup

COMPLICATIONS: Transient desaturation to 88% during procedure, resolved with increased FiO2

IMPRESSION: BAL obtained for infectious workup in immunocompromised host. Await results.

Dr. Nancy Adams, MD

BRONCHOSCOPY NOTE - URGENT
Date: 2024-03-24
Patient: Jerry Mitchell | MRN: 1331345 | Age: 3 years, Male
Attending: Dr. Patricia Lee, MD (Pediatric IP)
Location: Children's Hospital of Philadelphia

INDICATION: 18-year-old male with witnessed aspiration of peanut 2 hours ago. Stridor, decreased breath sounds on right.

PROCEDURE: Rigid bronchoscopy with foreign body removal

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia (sevoflurane induction, propofol maintenance)

- Vocal cords: Edematous
- Trachea: Mucosal inflammation
- Right mainstem: Peanut fragment lodged at RMS/BI junction causing complete obstruction
- Left lung: Normal

PROCEDURE: Using 3.5mm pediatric rigid bronchoscope, the peanut was visualized. Optical forceps used to grasp and remove the foreign body en bloc. Post-removal inspection showed mucosal edema and erythema but patent airway. Second fragment found in RLL, also removed.

SPECIMENS: Peanut fragments x 2 (gross specimen)

COMPLICATIONS: None

POST-PROCEDURE: Dexamethasone 0.5mg/kg IV given. Patient extubated, stridor resolved. Admission for overnight observation and racemic epinephrine PRN.

Dr. Patricia Lee, MD

note_text:
BLVR PROCEDURE NOTE
Date: 2024-08-14
Patient: Dorothy Price | MRN: 6766087 | Age: 67M
Attending: Dr. Sarah Kim, MD
Location: Temple University Hospital, Philadelphia, PA

INDICATION: Severe heterogeneous emphysema, upper lobe predominant, hyperinflation with RV 240%. FEV1 28% predicted. CT shows intact fissures. Candidate for endobronchial valve therapy (BLVR).

1. Flexible bronchoscopy
2. Chartis collateral ventilation assessment (LUL)
3. Endobronchial valve placement (LUL)

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia

LUL evaluated using Chartis system via balloon catheter at LB1+2 combined orifice:
- Adequate seal obtained
- Measurement duration: 5 minutes
- Flow pattern: Decreasing to zero
- Result: CV NEGATIVE (favorable for valve therapy)

Based on CV negative result and CT planning, Zephyr valves (Pulmonx) placed:
1. LB1+2: Zephyr 5.5mm - deployed, seal confirmed
2. LB3: Zephyr 5.0mm - deployed, seal confirmed  
3. LB4+5 (Lingula): Zephyr 4.0-LP - deployed, seal confirmed
4. LB6: Zephyr 5.5mm - deployed, seal confirmed

Total: 4 Zephyr valves placed in complete LUL lobar occlusion

Post-procedure bronchoscopy confirmed all valves seated with no visible air leak.

COMPLICATIONS: None
DISPOSITION: Admit overnight for pneumothorax monitoring. CXR q6h x 24hr.

FOLLOW-UP: CT chest in 6-8 weeks, PFTs at 3 months, 6 months.

Dr. Sarah Kim, MD

note_text:
THERAPEUTIC BRONCHOSCOPY NOTE
Date: 2025-01-13
Patient: Nathan Peterson | MRN: 9849969 | Age: 59F
Attending: Dr. Kevin Park, MD
Fellow: Dr. Jennifer Walsh, MD (PGY-6)
Location: MD Anderson Cancer Center, Houston, TX

INDICATION: Stage IIIB non-small cell lung cancer with near-complete obstruction of left mainstem bronchus causing post-obstructive pneumonia and respiratory failure. Palliative airway recanalization.

1. Rigid bronchoscopy
2. Tumor debulking with rigid coring/mechanical debridement
3. Argon plasma coagulation (APC) for hemostasis and tumor ablation
4. Balloon dilation
5. Silicone stent placement, left mainstem

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia, jet ventilation

FINDINGS & PROCEDURE:
Under GA, rigid bronchoscope (12mm Dumon) introduced. 
- Trachea: Patent
- Carina: Normal
- Right lung: Patent
- Left mainstem: >95% occluded by exophytic, necrotic tumor arising from posterolateral wall

Rigid coring performed to remove bulk of intraluminal tumor. Significant necrotic debris evacuated. APC (ERBE, 40W) applied for hemostasis and ablation of residual tumor at margins. Estimated 80% tumor removed with resulting lumen ~10mm.

CRE balloon (15mm x 40mm) used to dilate narrowed segment to accept stent. 3 inflations at 6 ATM.

Novatech Dumon silicone stent (14mm x 40mm) deployed over the debulked segment. Good expansion. Proximal and distal ends 1cm beyond visible tumor.

POST-PROCEDURE:
- Pre-obstruction: >95%
- Post-procedure: <20% (patent stent lumen)
- LLL and lingula now ventilated

SPECIMENS: Tumor fragments to surgical pathology
COMPLICATIONS: Moderate bleeding - controlled with APC
EBL: 75mL
DISPOSITION: SICU overnight then step-down

Dr. Kevin Park, MD

code_rationales.31641: Tumor destruction/debulking using mechanical and APC modalities
code_rationales.31630: Balloon dilation - may require modifier if at same site as stent per NCCI

coding_review.overall_assessment: Complex CAO with multimodal debulking and stent placement for malignant obstruction.

Date: 2025-07-24

Attending: Dr. Michael Roberts, MD
Location: University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA

INDICATION: Progressive ILD with UIP pattern on HRCT. Multidisciplinary discussion recommends tissue diagnosis to guide therapy. TBLC (transbronchial lung cryobiopsy) preferred over surgical lung biopsy given comorbidities.

1. Flexible bronchoscopy
2. Transbronchial cryobiopsy (RLL, 2 sites)
3. BAL (RML)

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia with ETT, blocker on standby

Under GA, bronchoscope advanced. Airways inspected - no endobronchial lesions.

BAL performed in RML (120mL instilled, 65mL return).

TBLC performed in RLL using 1.9mm cryoprobe (Erbe):

Site 1 - RB9:
- Fluoroscopy confirmed position 2cm from pleural surface
- Freeze time: 5 seconds x 3 biopsies
- Specimens 4-5mm, excellent quality
- Mild bleeding, controlled with Fogarty balloon

Site 2 - RB10:
- Freeze time: 5 seconds x 2 biopsies
- Specimens 3-4mm, good quality
- Minimal bleeding

Total: 5 cryobiopsies from 2 sites

No pneumothorax on completion fluoroscopy.

SPECIMENS: Cryobiopsy RLL x 5 (surgical pathology for ILD workup)
COMPLICATIONS: Mild bleeding - controlled with blocker
DISPOSITION: 4-hour observation, CXR, discharge if stable

note_text:
TRANSBRONCHIAL CRYOBIOPSY NOTE
Date: 2024-12-15
Patient: Martha Mendoza | MRN: 2224273 | Age: 62F
Attending: Dr. Michael Roberts, MD
Location: University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA

INDICATION: Progressive ILD with UIP pattern on HRCT. Multidisciplinary discussion recommends tissue diagnosis to guide therapy. TBLC (transbronchial lung cryobiopsy) preferred over surgical lung biopsy given comorbidities.

PROCEDURE:
1. Flexible bronchoscopy
2. Transbronchial cryobiopsy (RLL, 2 sites)
3. BAL (RML)

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia with ETT, blocker on standby

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
Under GA, bronchoscope advanced. Airways examined - no endobronchial lesions.

BAL executed in RML (120mL infused, 65mL return).

TBLC executed in RLL using 1.9mm cryoprobe (Erbe):

Site 1 - RB9:
- Fluoroscopy corroborated position 2cm from pleural surface
- Freeze time: 5 seconds x 3 biopsies
- Specimens 4-5mm, excellent quality
- Mild bleeding, controlled with Fogarty balloon

Site 2 - RB10:
- Freeze time: 5 seconds x 2 biopsies
- Specimens 3-4mm, good quality
- Minimal bleeding

Total: 5 cryobiopsies from 2 sites

No pneumothorax on completion fluoroscopy.

SPECIMENS: Cryobiopsy RLL x 5 (surgical pathology for ILD workup)
COMPLICATIONS: Mild bleeding - controlled with blocker
DISPOSITION: 4-hour observation, CXR, discharge if stable

Dr. Michael Roberts, MD
